{"step_by_step_thinking": "Plaque is a sticky, colorless film of bacteria that constantly forms on our teeth and along the gum line. Plaque contains bacteria that cause cavities and gum disease. As we eat food and drink liquids, these substances mix with the bacteria in plaque and form acids. These acids can damage tooth enamel and lead to cavities. The gingival third of the tooth surface is closest to the gum line, where plaque is most likely to accumulate due to the difficulty of cleaning this area thoroughly. Therefore, the gingival third of the tooth surface is the most likely to have the most plaque.", "answer_choice": "A"}
